instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Arrived with minor  liquid damage and stuck at 5v. <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> LDOs are good.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.30V <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V

LPS2R and AWAKE voltages are all 0v not shorted.

L7806-L7809 around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> are all OL diode mode

<SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> 0v

Does this sound like bad <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>??? Should anything else be checked?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is only 0.250V but cant find what creates it on schematic. Not shorted .380 diode mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Do not expect <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> yet; <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is not working, nor T2.

Check <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V"
Do you mean <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>?
<RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> is connected there, but doesn't get voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> actually 0v

I mixed up measurement with the present PP3V3 _LDO

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Looks like a bad <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>. <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> was 0v and shorted. Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> 

<SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> now present 5v <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H</SIGNAL> present 12.30V <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> still 0v

Replaced <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> from donar but no change. Also changed <CAPACITOR>C6903</CAPACITOR>.

Ordered some replacement TPS chipsets will update once replaced again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Did you check <CAPACITOR>C6900</CAPACITOR> voltage?
Be sure <RESISTOR>R6900</RESISTOR> is good; also check <RESISTOR>R6907</RESISTOR>.

Diode mode to ground at L6900?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C6900</CAPACITOR> 12.30V

<RESISTOR>R6900</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6907</RESISTOR> are good

diode mode L69000.340

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check all <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>-13 and traces.
If all good, change <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> again.
